author: John Cross
title: Here's why we should expect a late transfer window spending spree - but at the bottom end of the table
text:
Crystal Palace signing Jeffrey Schlupp (Photo: Crystal Palace Football Club) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
THE transfer window has produced some big stories but few big deals so far. 
Chelsea have been involved in two of the biggest stories because of Oscar’s £80m move to China and Diego Costa’s fall-out after having his head turned by Chinese millions. 
But none of the top six - Chelsea, Arsenal , Liverpool , Tottenham , Manchester United and Manchester City - have yet to make any big signings. 
They still have time of course before next Tuesday’s deadline but we might see a familiar pattern emerge. 
One expert predicts that this year’s spending will be just as high as last year’s £175m spurge and it will be the bottom clubs who are really busy. Martin Olsson has moved from Norwich to Swansea for £5m (Photo: Michael Regan/Getty) 
And the reasoning is very simple: the cost of relegation is actually higher than the rewards of being champions. 
That is the plain truth of the wealth of the Premier League thanks to huge TV deals and match day revenues and it is why the struggling clubs will gamble big before the window shuts. 
So far, we’ve seen wheeling and dealing with Crystal Palace boss Sam Allardyce spending a whacking £9m on Jeffrey Schlupp and doubling his wages to £60,000-a-week from what he was on at Leicester. 
Swansea boss Paul Lambert immediately spent big and one of his signings, Martin Olsson , cost £5m from Norwich . 
Hull , Burnley , West Ham and Sunderland have also tried to be busy as they fight for survival while the bigger clubs clearly feel they are going well enough already. Chelsea's Nemanja Matic has been a January window success story (Photo: Shaun Botterill) 
In the past, title chasers have spent big with Chelsea particularly good advocates of the January window as the signings of Nemanja Matic and David Luiz good examples. 
Arsenal even bought Jose Antonio Reyes in 2004 and he is often dismissed as a disaster who got homesick but you could argue his arrival in January 2004 gave them a turn boost to the title. 
But now the big deals are done at the other end and football finance expert Anna Semens, Head of Analytics at HSE Cake, makes it very clear as to why. 
Semens said: “The transfer window so far has been relatively quiet in terms of big deals, but that’s not too surprising and it looks like spending will probably reach a similar level to this time last year overall. 
“While the top teams competing for the title tend to invest heavily in the summer window, January tends to see more action at the lower end, with clubs competing to avoid relegation. TV deals are worth millions more in the Premier League (Photo: Michael Steele) 
“Avoiding relegation is in many ways worth more than actually winning the league, with Premier League status worth around £100m to a club with guaranteed TV revenue as well as a higher level of sponsorship fees - a shirt sponsorship deal for the bottom Premier League clubs could be as much as ten times that of Championship clubs. 
“This window in particular seems to have been characterised by a redistribution of power between players, clubs and agents with rumours of big money moves to China (and elsewhere) testing the resolve of clubs to hold on to their best players. 
“This influx of spending from a new market can create more options for players and in the short term at least, is likely to push up wages of the very best players that clubs don’t want to lose.” Like us on Facebook
